entry.title: Welcome Aanchal :)
entry.content: We are happy to welcome Aanchal Acharya to the Fong Lab! Aanchal is a first year Neuroscience undergraduate at Georgia Tech. She plans to pursue medical school and hopes to become a neurosurgeon focused on treating neurological disorders and reducing stigma around neurodivergence. She will be conducting research with Max on studying how temporary visual deprivation affects auditory and visual cortical plasticity in adult mice. Welcome Aanchal!

entry.title: Welcome Audrey :)
entry.content: We are pleased to welcome Audrey Garlick to the Fong Lab! Audrey is a first-year undergraduate studying Neuroscience at Georgia Tech with broad interests in learning, plasticity, and neurological disease. She is particularly interested in neurodegenerative disorders and hopes to pursue an MD-PhD in the future. In the lab, Audrey will study how optogenetic manipulation of neural circuits drives thalamocortical plasticity in mice under the mentorship of PhD candidate Yichao Zhao. Welcome, Audrey!

entry.title: Welcome Eli :)
entry.content: We are happy to welcome Elijah Lapeza to the Fong Lab for a research rotation. Eli is a first-year PhD student in GT-Emory Biomedical Engineering Program and a fellow in the NIBIB T32 Computational Neural Engineering Training Program. Eli is interested in neural plasticity and rehabilitation, and joins the lab to work on projects related to how early life experiences shapes neural responses in the mature mammalian visual system. Welcome, Eli!

entry.title: Danielle awarded AAUW International Fellowship
entry.content: Big news! Danielle Dowe has been awarded the prestigious AAUW International Fellowship for doctoral students. The fellowship will support her research on learning and homeostasis in biologically-plausible neural networks. We are thrilled to have an AAUW fellow in our ranks! Congratulations, Danielle!

entry.title: Welcome Sydney :)
entry.content: We are thrilled to welcome Sydney Gaines to the Fong Lab! Sydney is a high school student researcher in Project ENGAGES at Georgia Tech and is passionate about neuroscience and biotechnology. She brings a strong commitment to leadership and advocacy through her involvement in student organizations. In the lab, Sydney is excited to learn, grow as a researcher, and explore how neuroscience and technology can make a positive impact in healthcare. Welcome, Sydney!

entry.title: Welcome Alissa :)
entry.content: Alissa Klein is the newest member of the Fong Lab! Alissa is an undergraduate student at Georgia Tech majoring in Biomedical Engineering and joins our lab through the Emory Ophthalmology SEE Intern Program. She will be conducting research in the lab with Morgan and Adam, while also shadowing clinical ophthalmologists at Emory. Welcome, Alissa!

entry.title: Morgan and Chao present at ARVO

link.title: Morgan and Chao present at ARVO

entry.content: Morgan and Chao both received travel awards to presented their research at the ARVO conference in Salt Lake City. Morgan presented evidence that topical application of an mGlu6 blocker to the corneal surface can reach the retina to influence luminance processing in both the eye and brain, work conducted in collaboration with Reece Mazade and Machelle Pardue at Emory. Chao presented his research characterizing how optogenetic stimulation of the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus influences acute and long-lasting activity in primary visual cortex, work carried out with the help of Max Cao.

entry.title: Izzy and Max present at Eye Connect

link.title: Izzy and Max present at Eye Connect

entry.content: Izzy and Max presented posters on their rotation projects at the Eye Connect Symposium at Emory. Izzy presented her work on asymmetric impacts of ocular dominance plasticity on the ON and OFF pathways. Max presented his work on the reliability and precision of optogenetic thalamic stimulation on visual cortical activation. The new findings they produced in just 2 months was impressive! Special thanks to Chao, Morgan, and Adam for providing mentorship and contributing data to these presentations.

entry.title: Danielle presents at ASNR
entry.content: Danielle presented her research at the American Society for Neurorehabilitation annual meeting. Her work highlighted the divergent consequences of different homeostatic plasticity rules on neural circuit recovery following loss of vision.
